statement.p:
Consider the matrix and vectors
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 8 \amp -10 \\ 5 \amp -7 \\ \end{array}\right],\qquad \vvec_1=\twovec{2}{1},~~~ \vvec_2=\twovec{1}{1} .
Show that \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are eigenvectors of A and find their associated eigenvalues.
Express the vector \xvec = \twovec{-4}{-1} as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
Use this expression to compute A\xvec, A^2\xvec, and A^{-1}\xvec as a linear combination of eigenvectors.

li.p: We find that A\vvec_1 = 3\vvec_1 and A\vvec_2=-2\vvec_2 so the associated eigenvalues are \lambda_1 = 3 and \lambda_2=-2.
Setting up an augmented matrix and row reducing shows us that \xvec=\twovec{-4}{-1} = -3\vvec_1 + 2\vvec_2.
We find that A\vvec_1 = 3\vvec_1 and A\vvec_2=-2\vvec_2 so the associated eigenvalues are \lambda_1 = 3 and \lambda_2=-2.
\xvec=\twovec{-4}{-1} = -3\vvec_1 + 2\vvec_2.

statement.p:
Consider the matrix and vectors
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -5 \amp -2 \amp 2 \\ 24 \amp 14 \amp -10 \\ 21 \amp 14 \amp -10 \\ \end{array}\right],\qquad \vvec_1=\threevec{1}{-2}{-1}, \vvec_2=\threevec{2}{-3}{0}, \vvec_3=\threevec{0}{-1}{-1}
Show that the vectors \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 are eigenvectors of A and find their associated eigenvalues.
Express the vector \xvec = \threevec{0}{-3}{-4} as a linear combination of the eigenvectors.
Use this expression to compute A\xvec, A^2\xvec, and A^{-1}\xvec as a linear combination of eigenvectors.

li.p: We see that A\vvec_1=-3\vvec_1, A\vvec_2 = -2\vvec_2, and A\vvec_3=4\vvec_3. The associated eigenvalues are \lambda_1 = -3, \lambda_2=-2, and \lambda_3=4.
After forming an augmented matrix, we find \xvec=2\vvec_1 -\vvec_2+2\vvec_3.

We then have
\begin{alignedat}{4} A\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -6\vvec_1 \amp{}+{}\amp 2\vvec_2\amp{}+{} \amp 8\vvec_3\\ A^2\xvec\amp{}={}\amp 18\vvec_1\amp{}-{}\amp 4\vvec_2\amp{}+{}\amp 32\vvec_3\\ A^{-1}\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -\frac23\vvec_1\amp {}+{}\amp\frac12\vvec_2\amp{}+{}\amp\frac12\vvec_3\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat}
We see that A\vvec_1=-3\vvec_1, A\vvec_2 = -2\vvec_2, and A\vvec_3=4\vvec_3. The associated eigenvalues are \lambda_1 = -3, \lambda_2=-2, and \lambda_3=4.
\xvec=2\vvec_1 -\vvec_2+2\vvec_3.

We find
\begin{alignedat}{4} A\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -6\vvec_1 \amp{}+{}\amp 2\vvec_2\amp{}+{} \amp 8\vvec_3\\ A^2\xvec\amp{}={}\amp 18\vvec_1\amp{}-{}\amp 4\vvec_2\amp{}+{}\amp 32\vvec_3\\ A^{-1}\xvec\amp{}={}\amp -\frac23\vvec_1\amp {}+{}\amp\frac12\vvec_2\amp{}+{}\amp\frac12\vvec_3\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat}

statement.p:
Suppose that A is an n\times n matrix.
Explain why \lambda = 0 is an eigenvalue of A if and only if there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = 0.
Explain why A is not invertible if and only if \lambda=0 is an eigenvalue.
If \vvec is an eigenvector of A having associated eigenvalue \lambda, explain why \vvec is also an eigenvector of A^2 with associated eigenvalue \lambda^2.
If A is invertible and \vvec is eigenvector of A having associated eigenvalue \lambda, explain why \vvec is also an eigenvector of A^{-1} with associated eigenvalue \lambda^{-1}.
The matrix
A=\ \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]
has eigenvectors \vvec_1=\twovec{1}{1} and \vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{1} and associated eigenvalues \lambda_1 = 3 and \lambda=-1. What are some eigenvectors and associated eigenvalues for A^5?

li.p: If \lambda=0 is an eigenvalue, then there is a nonzero vector \vvec such that A\vvec=\lambda\vvec = \zerovec. This means that an associated eigenvector is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec.
If \lambda =0 is an eigenvalue of A, then there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec, which happens exactly when A is not invertible.

If \vvec is an eigenvector of A with associated eigenvalue \lambda, then A\vvec=\lambda\vvec. Therefore, A^2\vvec = A(A\vvec) = \lambda A\vvec = \lambda^2\vvec, which means that \vvec is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda^2.

If A\vvec=\lambda\vvec, we can multiply both sides by A^{-1} and \frac1\lambda to obtain \frac1\lambda\vvec=A^{-1}\vvec. This shows that \vvec is an eigenvector of A^{-1} with associated eigenvalue \frac1\lambda.
The vectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are eigenvectors of A^5 with associated eigenvalues \lambda_1^5 = 3^5=243 and \lambda_2^5 = (-1)^5 = -1.
If \lambda=0 is an eigenvalue, then there is a nonzero vector \vvec such that A\vvec=\lambda\vvec = \zerovec.
If \lambda =0 is an eigenvalue of A, then there is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec.
If A\vvec=\lambda\vvec, we can multiply both sides by A^{-1} and \frac1\lambda to obtain \frac1\lambda\vvec=A^{-1}\vvec.
Notice that A^2\vvec = A(A\vvec) = \lambda A\vvec = \lambda^2\vvec, which means that \vvec is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda^2.
The vectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are eigenvectors of A^5 with associated eigenvalues \lambda_1^5 = 3^5=243 and \lambda_2^5 = (-1)^5 = -1.

For the following matrices, find the eigenvectors and associated eigenvalues by thinking geometrically about the corresponding matrix transformation.
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rr} -2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right] .
What are the eigenvectors and associated eigenvalues of the identity matrix?
What are the eigenvectors and associated eigenvalues of a diagonal matrix with distinct diagonal entries?

li.p: The corresponding matrix transformation stretches every two-dimensional vector by a factor of 3. Therefore, every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda=3.

The corresponding matrix transformation stretches vectors horizontally by a factor of 2 and reflects them while stretching by a factor of 4 vertically. We have eigenvectors \vvec_1=\twovec{1}{0} with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=-2 and \vvec_2=\twovec{0}{1} with \lambda_2=4.
For any vector \vvec, we have I\vvec=\vvec. Therefore, every vector is an eigenvector of the identity matrix with associated eigenvalue \lambda=1.
The standard basis vectors \evec_j are eigenvectors and the associated eigenvalues are the corresponding diagonal entries.
Every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda=3.
We have eigenvectors \vvec_1=\twovec{1}{0} with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=-2 and \vvec_2=\twovec{0}{1} with \lambda_2=4.
Every vector is an eigenvector of the identity matrix with associated eigenvalue \lambda=1.
The standard basis vectors \evec_j are eigenvectors and the associated eigenvalues are the corresponding diagonal entries.

statement.p:
Suppose that A is a 2\times2 matrix having eigenvectors
\vvec_1=\twovec{2}{1}, \qquad \vvec_2=\twovec{-1}{2}
and associated eigenvalues \lambda_1=2 and \lambda_2=-3.
If \xvec=\twovec{5}{0}, find the vector A^4\xvec.
Find the vectors A\twovec10 and A\twovec01.
What is the matrix A?

li.p: We have \xvec = 2\vvec_1-\vvec_2. Therefore, A^4\xvec = 2\lambda_1^4\vvec_1-\lambda_2^4\vvec_2 = 32\vvec_1-81\vvec_2=\twovec{145}{-130}.

We have
\twovec10 = \frac25 \vvec_1 - \frac15 \vvec2,~~~ \twovec01 = \frac15 \vvec_1 + \frac25 \vvec2,
and so
A\twovec10 = \frac45 \vvec_1 + \frac35 \vvec2 = \twovec12,~~~ A\twovec01 = \frac25 \vvec_1 - \frac65 \vvec2 = \twovec2{-2}.
A\twovec10 = \twovec12 and A\twovec01 = \twovec2{-2}.

statement.p:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false and provide a justification for your response.
The eigenvalues of a diagonal matrix are equal to the entries on the diagonal.
If A\vvec=\lambda\vvec, then A^2\vvec=\lambda\vvec as well.
Every vector is an eigenvector of the identity matrix.
If \lambda=0 is an eigenvalue of A, then A is invertible.
For every n\times n matrix A, it is possible to find a basis of \real^n consisting of eigenvectors of A.

False. A^2\vvec=\lambda^2\vvec.

False. We saw the example \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right], which represents a 90^\circ rotation and has no eigenvectors.

statement.p:
Suppose that A is an n\times n matrix.
Assuming that \vvec is an eigenvector of A whose associated eigenvalue is nonzero, explain why \vvec is in \col(A).
Assuming that \vvec is an eigenvector of A whose associated eigenvalue is zero, explain why \vvec is in \nul(A).
Consider the two special matrices below and find their eigenvectors and associated eigenvalues.
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right],~~~ B = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 3 \amp 3 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right].

li.p: In this case, we have A\vvec = \lambda\vvec or A\left(\frac1\lambda\vvec\right) = \vvec, which says that the equation A\xvec = \vvec is consistent.
With this assumption, A\vvec = 0\vvec = \zerovec, which means that \vvec is a solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec.
The column space of A is spanned by \vvec_1=\threevec{1}{1}{1} and we notice that A\vvec_1 = 3\vvec_1. Therefore, \vvec_1 is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=3.

We also know that that the rank of this matrix is 1 so \nul(A) is two-dimensional. A basis for the null space is \vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{1}{0} and \vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{0}{1} so these vectors are eigenvectors with associated eigenvalue \lambda_2=\lambda_3 = 0.
In the same way, \vvec_1=\threevec{1}{2}{3} is an eigenvector of B with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=6 and \vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{1}{0} and \vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{0}{1} are eigenvectors with associated eigenvalue \lambda_2=\lambda_3=0.
Because A\vvec = \lambda\vvec.
Because A\vvec = 0\vvec = \zerovec.

For the matrix A, \vvec_1=\threevec{1}{1}{1} with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=3, and \vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{1}{0} and \vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{0}{1} with associated eigenvalue \lambda_2=\lambda_3 = 0.
For B, \vvec_1=\threevec{1}{2}{3} with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=6 and \vvec_2=\threevec{-1}{1}{0} and \vvec_3=\threevec{-1}{0}{1} with associated eigenvalue \lambda_2=\lambda_3=0.

statement.p:
For each of the following matrix transformations, describe the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the corresponding matrix A.
A reflection in \real^2 in the line y=x.
A 180^\circ rotation in \real^2.
A 180^\circ rotation in \real^3 about the y-axis.
A 90^\circ rotation in \real^3 about the x-axis.

li.p: A vector lying along the line of reflection is unchanged so A\twovec{1}{1} = \twovec{1}{1}, which shows that \twovec{1}{1} is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda = 1. At the same time, A\twovec{1}{-1} = -\twovec{1}{-1} so \twovec{1}{-1} is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda=-1.
Every vector \vvec satisfies A\vvec=-\vvec so every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda=-1.

Vectors along the y-axis are unchanged so \threevec{0}{1}{0} is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda=1. Vectors in the xz-plane are multiplied by -1 so \threevec{1}{0}{0} and \threevec{0}{0}{1} are eigenvectors with associated eigenvalue \lambda=-1.
The vector \threevec{1}{0}{0} is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda=1. There are no other eigenvectors that are not scalar multiples of this one.
\twovec{1}{1} with associated eigenvalue \lambda = 1 and \twovec{1}{-1} with associated eigenvalue \lambda=-1.
Every two-dimensional vector is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda=-1.
\threevec{0}{1}{0} with associated eigenvalue \lambda=1. \threevec{1}{0}{0} and \threevec{0}{0}{1} with associated eigenvalue \lambda=-1.
\threevec{1}{0}{0} with associated eigenvalue \lambda=1.

statement.p:
Suppose we have two species, P and Q, where species P preys on Q. Their populations, in millions, in year k are denoted by P_k and Q_k and satisfy
\begin{aligned} P_{k+1} \amp {}={} 0.8P_k + 0.2Q_k \\ Q_{k+1} \amp {}={} -0.3P_k + 1.5Q_k \\ \end{aligned} . We will keep track of the populations in year k using the vector \xvec_k=\twovec{P_k}{Q_k} so that
\xvec_{k+1} = A\xvec_k = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 0.8 \amp 0.2 \\ -0.3 \amp 1.5 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec_k .
Show that \vvec_1=\twovec{1}{3} and \vvec_2=\twovec{2}{1} are eigenvectors of A and find their associated eigenvalues.
Suppose that the initial populations are described by the vector \xvec_0 = \twovec{38}{44}. Express \xvec_0 as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
Find the populations after one year, two years, and three years by writing the vectors \xvec_1, \xvec_2, and \xvec_3 as linear combinations of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
What is the general form for \xvec_k?
After a very long time, what is the ratio of P_k to Q_k?

li.p: We can compute A\vvec_1 = 1.4\vvec_1 and A\vvec_2=0.9\vvec_2. This means that \vvec_1 is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=1.4 and \vvec_2 is an eigenvector with associated eigenvalue \lambda_2=0.9.
Setting up an augmented matrix and row reducing shows that \xvec_0=10\vvec_1+14\vvec_2.

We have
\begin{alignedat}{4} \xvec_1\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_0 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_1 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)^2\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)^2\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_2 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)^3\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)^3\vvec_2\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat}
In general, \xvec_k = 10(1.4)^k\vvec_1 + 14(0.9)^k\vvec_2.

After a long time, k becomes large so that 0.9^k becomes very close to zero. This means that \xvec_k\approx 10(1.4)^k\vvec_1. So P_k\approx10(1.4)^k and Q_k\approx30(1.4)^k. This means the ratio of P_k to Q_k is 1:3.
\vvec_1 with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=1.4 and \vvec_2 with associated eigenvalue \lambda_2=0.9.
\xvec_0=10\vvec_1+14\vvec_2.

We have
\begin{alignedat}{4} \xvec_1\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_0 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_2\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_1 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)^2\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)^2\vvec_2 \\ \xvec_3\amp{}={}\amp A\xvec_2 \amp {}={} 10(1.4)^3\vvec_1 \amp {}+{} \amp 14(0.9)^3\vvec_2\text{.} \\ \end{alignedat}
In general, \xvec_k = 10(1.4)^k\vvec_1 + 14(0.9)^k\vvec_2.
The ratio of P_k to Q_k is 1:3.
